prompt: Alice Smith is a new hourly employee in California. She earns $25 per hour and worked 80 regular hours this pay period. She's married filing jointly and indicated that either she has two jobs or her spouse works. She wants an extra $150 withheld from each paycheck. She didn't claim any dependents, other income, or deductions. When you set up her California state withholding, just use whatever the standard default option is and set allowances to zero. Run an off-cycle payroll for her and capture a screenshot of the final pay stub showing her net pay.

Bob Jones is a salaried non-exempt employee in California earning $4,000 per month. Since the company pays semi-monthly, his standard hours for each pay period are 86.67 hours. This period he worked 10 hours of overtime at 1.5 times his hourly equivalent rate. He's single and doesn't have a second job. He claimed $2,000 in dependents, reported $500 in other income, and wants an extra $47 withheld each period. Use the default state withholding settings with zero allowances. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Carol Brown is a piece-rate worker in Texas. She worked 40 hours this period and earned $200 in piece-rate earnings. Texas requires that piece-rate workers receive at least minimum wage of $7.25 per hour for all hours worked. You need to add a "Minimum Wage Make-up" payment to bring her total gross pay up to the legal minimum. She's single with no second job, no dependents, no other income or deductions, and no extra withholding. Process the payroll and capture the pay stub.

David Lee is an hourly employee in California earning $18 per hour. He worked 86.67 regular hours this period. He's filing as head of household and claimed $6,000 in dependents. He doesn't have a second job, no other income, no deductions, and no extra withholding. Use standard California state withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Erin White is an hourly employee in California earning $42 per hour. She worked 80 regular hours this period. She's filing as head of household and has two jobs. She claimed $8,000 in dependents, reported $2,500 in other income, and wants an extra $275 withheld each paycheck. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Frank Green is a Nevada employee who worked in two different roles this period. He worked 30 hours at $25 per hour and 20 hours at $40 per hour. Since he worked more than 40 hours total, the 10 overtime hours require a weighted-average blended rate calculation. Pay him all hours at their straight-time rates, then add an overtime premium equal to 0.5 times the blended rate times 10 overtime hours. He's married filing jointly with two jobs, no dependents, and wants $65 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Grace King is a California employee earning $22 per hour. Her timecard: Monday 14 hours, Tuesday through Friday 8 hours each day, weekend off. Apply California's daily overtime rules: hours over 8 up to 12 in a day are overtime at 1.5 times, hours over 12 in a day are double time at 2 times. Calculate the correct regular, overtime, and double time hours, enter them in payroll, and capture the pay stub.

Henry Hall is a California employee earning $20 per hour who worked 50 hours this period. He also earned a $500 nondiscretionary bonus. When a nondiscretionary bonus is paid in a period with overtime, it increases the regular rate for overtime purposes. Pay the regular and overtime hours at the base rate, then calculate and add an "OT Adjustment" for the additional overtime premium caused by the bonus. Process the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Ivy Clark is a California employee with a semi-monthly base pay of $5,000. She also received a $1,000 bonus this period. She has traditional 401(k) at 6% of eligible wages and Roth 401(k) at 3% of eligible wages. She's married filing jointly with no second job, no dependents, and no extra withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Jack Davis is a California employee with a semi-monthly base pay of $4,000. He has pre-tax Section 125 medical deductions: $400 medical premium contribution and $200 medical premium. He's single with no second job, no dependents, and wants $25 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Kelly Moore is a California employee with a semi-monthly base pay of $3,000. She has traditional 401(k) at 10% of eligible wages and Section 125 medical premium of $500. She's filing as head of household with no second job and claimed $2,000 in dependents. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Liam Hill is a Texas employee. He worked 30 hours at $50 per hour and is receiving a $180,000 bonus. He has traditional 401(k) at 5% of eligible wages. The Social Security wage base cap for 2026 is approximately $176,100, so Social Security tax should only apply to wages up to that cap. He's single with no second job and no extra withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Maya Scott is a Texas employee. She worked 80 hours at $25 per hour and earned a $250,000 commission. She has Section 125 medical premium of $250. The Additional Medicare Tax of 0.9% applies to wages over $250,000 for married filing jointly. She's married filing jointly with two jobs and wants $200 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Noah Adams is a California employee receiving a $300,000 bonus this period. He has Roth 401(k) at 4% and Section 125 medical premium of $300. This will trigger both the Social Security wage base cap and Additional Medicare Tax. He's single with two jobs and wants $250 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Olivia Baker lives in Texas but works remotely for a company located in New York. She earns $60 per hour and worked 80 regular hours. Under New York's "convenience of employer" rule, New York state taxes apply even though she lives in Texas. She's single with no second job and no dependents. Set up New York state withholding and run the payroll. Capture the pay stub.

Paul Young is a California resident who splits his work across two states in the same pay period: 50 hours in California and 30 hours in Nevada at $45 per hour. You'll need to allocate his wages between the two states for proper tax withholding. He's married filing jointly with no second job and wants $75 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Quinn Allen is a California employee earning $30 per hour. This period she worked 80 regular hours and 10 overtime hours, plus received a $3,000 nondiscretionary bonus. The bonus increases the regular rate for overtime purposes, so you need to calculate and add an additional overtime premium adjustment. She's single with two jobs and wants $120 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Riley Ward is a California employee. She worked 80 hours at $25 per hour and is receiving a $10,000 sign-on bonus. She's single with no second job and wants $100 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Sam Wright is a California employee. He worked 20 hours at $25 per hour and earned a $15,000 commission. He's married filing jointly with two jobs and no extra withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Taylor Lopez is a California employee who is leaving the company. This final paycheck includes regular pay of 40 hours at $40 per hour and PTO payout of 60 hours at $40 per hour. She's filing as head of household with no second job, claimed $2,000 in dependents, and no extra withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Uma Ross is a Texas employee earning $25 per hour who worked 40 hours. She has a child support garnishment order for $1,500 per month. Apply standard limits to ensure the garnishment does not exceed the maximum allowed percentage of disposable earnings. She's single with no second job. Set up the child support garnishment, run the payroll, and capture the pay stub.

Vic Gray is a California employee earning $31.25 per hour who worked 80 hours. He's also receiving a $2,000 bonus. He has a child support garnishment of $1,400 per month capped at 50% of disposable income. He's married filing jointly with no second job and no extra withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Wendy Wood lives in New York but works in New Jersey. She earns $37.50 per hour and worked 80 hours. She has a child support garnishment order for $900 per month with a maximum of 55% of disposable income. She's single with no second job and no extra withholding. Set up both state withholding and the garnishment, then capture the pay stub.

Xavier Cruz is a California employee who started mid-period. He has an annual salary of $60,000 paid semi-monthly. This pay period has 10 workdays total, but he only worked 4 of those days, so his pay should be prorated accordingly. He's married filing jointly with no second job and no extra withholding. Run the payroll with the prorated amount and capture the pay stub.

Yara Nelson is a California employee earning $35 per hour. She worked 80 regular hours and is receiving a $5,000 bonus. She's single with no second job, no dependents, and no extra withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Zoe Carter is a California employee earning $25 per hour who worked 80 hours. She's also receiving an $800 retroactive pay adjustment as a separate earning. She's single with no second job and no extra withholding. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Alpha Roberts is a California executive. He worked 80 hours at $125 per hour and is receiving a $220,000 bonus. He has traditional 401(k) at 6% and Section 125 medical premium of $300. This will trigger the Social Security cap and Additional Medicare Tax. He's married filing jointly with two jobs and wants $500 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Beta Turner lives in New Jersey but works in New York. He worked in two different roles: 30 hours at $20 per hour and 20 hours at $30 per hour. Since he worked more than 40 hours total, the 10 overtime hours require a blended rate calculation with an overtime premium adjustment. He has a child support garnishment of $1,100 per month capped at 50% of disposable income. He's filing as head of household with no second job and claimed $2,000 in dependents. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Gamma Phillips is a California sales employee. He worked 80 hours at $25 per hour and earned a $220,000 commission. He has Section 125 medical premium of $250. This will trigger both SS cap and Additional Medicare Tax. He's single with two jobs and wants $250 extra withheld. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Delta Campbell is a California employee who was terminated. This final paycheck includes work split between two states: 40 hours in California at $40 per hour and 40 hours in Texas at $40 per hour. It also includes PTO payout of 200 hours at $40 per hour and a $200 retro adjustment. The employee is normally enrolled in traditional 401(k) at 10% and Section 125 medical premium of $300, but for this final payroll these deductions should be cancelled. He's married filing jointly with no second job. Run the final payroll and capture the pay stub.

Ava Parker is a Washington employee earning $28.50 per hour. She worked 72 regular hours and 12 overtime hours, plus received a $2,200 nondiscretionary bonus. The bonus affects the overtime rate calculation, so add an overtime adjustment for the additional premium. She's single with two jobs and wants $90 extra withheld. If Washington state tax questions appear, answer them with the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Ben Evans is a Washington employee who worked at multiple rates: 36 hours at $24 per hour and 24 hours at $38 per hour. The 8 overtime hours require a blended rate calculation. He's married filing jointly with no second job and claimed $1,000 in dependents. Answer any Washington state tax questions with the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Cara Edwards is a Washington employee. She worked 20 hours at $55 per hour and earned a $180,000 commission. She has traditional 401(k) at 6% and Section 125 medical premium of $300. This will trigger the Social Security wage base cap. She's filing as head of household with two jobs and wants $300 extra withheld. Answer Washington state tax questions with the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Dan Collins is a Pennsylvania employee earning $33.75 per hour. He worked 80 regular hours and received a $4,500 bonus. He has traditional 401(k) at 8%. He's married filing jointly with two jobs and wants $125 extra withheld. If Pennsylvania local tax questions appear, answer them using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Eli Stewart is an Ohio employee earning $29 per hour. He worked 80 regular hours and received an $1,800 bonus. He has a child support garnishment of $900 per month with a maximum of 50%. He's single with no second job. Answer any Ohio local tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Fay Morris lives in New Jersey but works in New York. She earns $44 per hour and worked 80 regular hours. She has Section 125 medical premium of $250 and traditional 401(k) at 5%. She's single with two jobs and wants $80 extra withheld. Answer any NY/NJ state tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Gus Rogers lives in New York but works in New Jersey. He earns $31.50 per hour and worked 80 hours. He has a New Jersey child support garnishment of $1,100 per month with a maximum of 55%. He's filing as head of household with no second job and claimed $2,000 in dependents. Answer any NY/NJ state tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Hana Reed is a Massachusetts employee earning $40 per hour who worked 40 hours. She earned a $120,000 commission. She's married filing jointly with two jobs and wants $250 extra withheld. Answer any Massachusetts state tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Ian Cook splits his work between Pennsylvania and New Jersey. He earns $36 per hour and worked 44 hours in PA and 36 hours in NJ. He received a $2,400 bonus. He's single with no second job. Answer any state tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Jade Morgan splits work between Ohio and Pennsylvania. She worked 30 hours at $26 per hour and 30 hours at $42 per hour. The 10 overtime hours require a blended rate calculation. She's married filing jointly with no second job. Answer any state/local tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Kai Bell splits work between Washington and California. He earns $35 per hour and worked 30 hours in WA and 50 hours in CA. He has traditional 401(k) at 7% and Section 125 medical premium of $300. He's single with two jobs and wants $60 extra withheld. Answer any state tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Lia Murphy lives in New Jersey but works in New York. She earns $27 per hour and worked 80 hours. She's single with no second job and no extra withholding. Answer any New York state tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Moe Bailey is a Pennsylvania employee earning $32 per hour. This final paycheck includes 20 regular hours, 18 hours of PTO payout, a $2,000 bonus, and $600 in retroactive pay. He's filing as head of household with two jobs and wants $110 extra withheld. Answer any Pennsylvania tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Nia Rivera is an Ohio employee earning $26 per hour. She worked 80 regular hours and 8 overtime hours, plus received a $1,600 nondiscretionary bonus. The bonus affects the overtime rate calculation. She's single with two jobs and wants $70 extra withheld. Answer any Ohio tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.

Omar Cooper is a Massachusetts employee earning $38 per hour who worked 40 hours. He earned a $60,000 commission. He has traditional 401(k) at 6%, Section 125 medical premium of $300, and a child support garnishment of $1,200 per month with a maximum of 50%. He's married filing jointly with no second job. Answer any Massachusetts tax questions using the options shown. Run the payroll and capture the pay stub.
